{{Infobox video game | title = Sunset Overdrive | image = Sunset Overdrive cover.jpg | caption = | developer = [[Insomniac Games]]{{efn|Ported to PC by Blind Squirrel Games.}} | publisher = [[Microsoft Studios]] | director = Marcus Smith
Drew Murray | producer = Bryan Intihar | designer = Cameron Christian | writer = Jon Paquette | artist = Jacinda Chew | programmer = Doug Sheahen | composer = Boris Salchow | engine = | platforms = {{Unbulleted list|[[Xbox One]]|[[Microsoft Windows]]}} | released = '''Xbox One'''{{vgrelease|NA|October 28, 2014|AUS|October 30, 2014|EU|October 31, 2014}}'''Microsoft Windows'''{{vgrelease|WW|November 16, 2018}} | genre = [[Action-adventure game|Action-adventure]], {{nowrap|[[third-person shooter]]}} | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Cooperative gameplay|multiplayer]]{{efn|Only the Xbox One version has multiplayer.}} }} '''''Sunset Overdrive''''' is an [[Action-adventure game|action-adventure]] [[third-person shooter]] [[video game]] developed by [[Insomniac Games]] and published by [[Microsoft Studios]]. It was announced at [[Electronic Entertainment Expo 2013]], and released worldwide for Xbox One in October 2014 and for Microsoft Windows in November 2018. The game is set in 2027, in a fictional [[metropolis]] called Sunset City. The player controls an employee of FizzCo, who has to fight off the OD, short for Overcharge Drinkers: humans who have turned into mutants after drinking FizzCo's energy drink beverage. In the dystopian Sunset City the player character can wall-run, use [[zip-line]]s, and [[grind rail]]s to swiftly navigate through it, with a large arsenal of weapons to use. The game also has a [[cooperative multiplayer]] mode called ''Chaos Squad'', which tasks players to complete a series of missions with seven players. As the game puts emphasis on momentum, the game does not feature any cover system. The development of the game began in 2010 when Insomniac completed ''[[Resistance 3]].'' After the project was green-lit internally, the studio partnered with Microsoft Studios, which helped fund the game and allowed Insomniac to keep the rights to the franchise. Insomniac described the game as a "celebration of games", as the team took inspiration from different sources, including ''[[Prince of Persia]]'', ''[[Jet Set Radio]]'' and ''[[Tony Hawk's Pro Skater]]'', though at its early stage of development the team took inspirations from ''[[DayZ (mod)|DayZ]]'' instead. The game is set in a post-apocalyptic future, but the team depicted it as an "awesomepocalypse" that turns the game's initial world depiction into a "playground" for players. ''Sunset Overdrive'' is powered by Insomniac's internal engine, previously used in ''[[Fuse (video game)|Fuse]]'', one of their previous games. The game received generally positive reviews, with praise for its visuals, traversal system, combat system, and humor. However, the game was criticized for the lack of a compelling story or innovative quest design. It received numerous nominations, including Best Xbox Game of the Year awards from several gaming publications. The game was supported with multiple [[downloadable content]], including the story-based ''The Mystery of the Mooil Rig'' and ''Dawn of the Rise of the Fallen Machine'', after the game's release. == Gameplay == [[File:Sunset Overdrive Xbox One gameplay screenshot.png|thumb|left|In ''Sunset Overdrive'', players can grind rails to navigate the game's world. The game's world, Sunset City, is portrayed with vibrant colors.]] ''Sunset Overdrive'' is an [[action-adventure game]] set in a [[third-person perspective]]. Players navigate a metropolis called Sunset City in the year 2027. This [[dystopian]] world has been overrun by mutants called the OD, short for Overcharge Drinkers. The [[player character]] is a former FizzCo employee, tasked with cleaning up the mess left behind from a party FizzCo had thrown to celebrate the launch of its new energy drink, Overcharge Delirium XT.{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/05/08/sunset-overdrive-open-world-adventures-in-the-awesomepocalypse |title=Sunset Overdrive: Open World Adventures in the Awesomepocalypse |date=May 8, 2014 |last=Moriarty |first=Colin |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] |work=[[IGN]] |accessdate=May 8, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuHXaWri?url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/05/08/sunset-overdrive-open-world-adventures-in-the-awesomepocalypse |archivedate=November 9, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} At the start of the game, players can customize the protagonist's gender, body type, hairstyle, and outfit using the character creator.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/sunset-overdrive-character-customization-lets-you-/1100-6421329/|title=Sunset Overdrive Character Customization Lets You Be Emo, Goth, Metal, And Everything In-Between|first=Emanuel|last=Maiberg |date=July 27, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|work=[[GameSpot]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151105155436/http://www.gamespot.com/articles/sunset-overdrive-character-customization-lets-you-/1100-6421329/|archivedate= 5 November 2015}} Players may also alter the look of their customized character at any point during the game by approaching a vendor named Callista.{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/tips-for-playing-sunset-overdrive-1651747942|title=Tips For Playing Sunset Overdrive|first=Yannick|last=LeJacq|date=October 28, 2015|accessdate=October 1, 2015|work=[[Kotaku]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151105160014/http://kotaku.com/tips-for-playing-sunset-overdrive-1651747942|archivedate=5 November 2015}} After creating their characters, players proceed to the game's [[open world]], which is free for players to explore at any time. A fast travel system is provided allowing players to reach different locations and to navigate the world quickly.{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/sunset_overdrive/b/xboxone/archive/2014/08/13/sunset-overdrive-makes-no-sense-but-we-like-it-that-way.aspx|title=Sunset Overdrive: Insomniac's Shooter Makes No Sense, But We Like It That Way|first=Ben|last=Reeves|work=[[Game Informer]]|date=August 13, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuHfh7Lj?url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/sunset_overdrive/b/xboxone/archive/2014/08/13/sunset-overdrive-makes-no-sense-but-we-like-it-that-way.aspx|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} The game features a main campaign with story elements and side-missions, which are triggered automatically when players enter certain locations in the city. These quests mainly involve players delivering objects to other [[non-playable characters]] and collecting items from the world. Some of these quests have time limits. Throughout the game, players encounter both human enemies, such as gang members, FizzCo's robots,{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/sunset_overdrive/b/xboxone/archive/2014/08/12/you-39-ll-be-fighting-more-than-monsters-and-competing-gangs.aspx|title=Sunset Overdrive: You'll Be Fighting More Than Monsters And Competing Gangs|first=Kyle|last=Hilliard|work=[[Game Informer]]|date=August 12, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuHiLgAh?url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/sunset_overdrive/b/xboxone/archive/2014/08/12/you-39-ll-be-fighting-more-than-monsters-and-competing-gangs.aspx|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} OD'd humans who have mutated from drinking too much of the energy drink, and several [[boss (gaming)|bosses]] who are more difficult to defeat compared with other ordinary enemies.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/01/02/the-best-boss-battles-of-2014|title=The Best Boss Battles Of 2014|work=[[IGN]]|date=January 2, 2015|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuHkmo9h?url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/01/02/the-best-boss-battles-of-2014|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} The game features a variety of weapons for players to use to combat enemies. These include the standard [[assault rifle]] AK-FU and the TNTeddy [[grenade launcher]], which fires teddy bears strapped to sticks of dynamite,{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/sunset_overdrive/b/xboxone/archive/2014/05/30/sunset-overdrive-sunset-tv-weapons.aspx|title=Sunset Overdrive's Exploding Teddy Bears & Vinyl Records|first=Matthew|last=Kato|work=[[Game Informer]]|date=May 30, 2014|accessdate=December 18, 2015}} fireworks and toy helicopters.{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/our-first-real-look-at-sunset-overdrive-1573151521|title=Our First Real Look At Sunset Overdrive|first=Phil|last=Owen|work=[[Kotaku]]|date=August 5, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuHmdaGI?url=http://kotaku.com/our-first-real-look-at-sunset-overdrive-1573151521|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} All weapons eventually run out of ammunition but do not need to be reloaded while being used. Players unlock more weapons by progressing through the story or purchasing them from shops. Weapons can be upgraded and modified by applying "Amps", which increases weapons' [[lethality]], efficiency, and strength. The weapons can be [[level (role-playing games)|leveled up]] when players earn enough [[experience (gaming)|experience points]] or defeat enough enemies with them. The game's combat focuses on velocity, and encourages players to defeat enemies in a fast-paced way. As a result, players can employ different moves including wall running, air-dashing, [[zip-line|zip lining]], performing [[parkour]], [[acrobatics]], and water traversal.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/09/17/sunset-overdrive-is-silly-stylish-and-incredibly-smart|title=Sunset Overdrive Is Silly, Stylish and Incredibly Smart|first=Mitch|last=Dyer|work=[[IGN]]|date=September 17, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuHtfH1f?url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/09/17/sunset-overdrive-is-silly-stylish-and-incredibly-smart|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}}{{cite web |url=http://www.polygon.com/2013/6/11/4417950/sunset-overdrive-turns-a-city-ravaged-by-catastrophe-into-your |title=Sunset Overdrive turns a city ravaged by catastrophe into your playground |last1=Lien |first1=Tracey |date=June 11, 2013 |work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |accessdate=June 15, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuHxgkEm?url=http://www.polygon.com/2013/6/11/4417950/sunset-overdrive-turns-a-city-ravaged-by-catastrophe-into-your |archivedate=November 9, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} Players use [[grind rail]]s to deftly navigate city streets, and are able to switch direction instantly at will. The city is also filled with items for players to bounce up into the air.{{cite web|url=http://www.usgamer.net/articles/sunset-overdrive-xbox-one-preview-leaving-all-that-grey-and-brown-behind|title=Sunset Overdrive Xbox One Preview: Leaving All That Grey and Brown Behind|first=Mike|last=Williams|work=[[USgamer]]|date=June 24, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuHzDpeV?url=http://www.usgamer.net/articles/sunset-overdrive-xbox-one-preview-leaving-all-that-grey-and-brown-behind|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} Players may utilize their weapons while performing these movements and slow down time for players to take aim. On-foot, players cannot walk, take cover, or take out enemies silently,{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/9/22/6553275/i-played-the-first-two-hours-of-sunset-overdrive-and-i-liked-it-a-lot|title=I played the first two hours of Sunset Overdrive and I liked it a lot|first=Colin|last=Campbell|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=September 22, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuI154WA?url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/9/22/6553275/i-played-the-first-two-hours-of-sunset-overdrive-and-i-liked-it-a-lot|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} but instead must rely on agility to survive as they will be overwhelmed quickly by enemies if they choose to walk on the ground. The game also features a Style Meter. Shown in the [[head-up display]] (HUD) of the game, the Meter increases as players perform stylish moves like killing enemies and grinding on-rails without touching the ground. When players are killed, they do not have to wait for the game to [[loading (computing)|load]]. Players can respawn and return to the world by different methods, such as descending with a rocket or exiting a golden sarcophagus.{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2014/05/08/slide-until-you-die-in-xbox-ones-crazy-sunset-overdrive/|title=Slide until you die in Xbox One's crazy Sunset Overdrive|first=Ludwig|last=Kietzmann|work=[[Joystiq]]|publisher=[[Engadget]]|date=May 8, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuI2Kn7z?url=http://www.engadget.com/2014/05/08/slide-until-you-die-in-xbox-ones-crazy-sunset-overdrive/|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} Insomniac named this system "Next-Gen Respawning".{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-05-19-sunset-overdrives-respawns-should-more-games-rethink-the-little-things|title=Sunset Overdrive's respawns: should more games rethink the little things?|first=Christian|last=Donlan|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=September 19, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuI5Uq9R?url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-05-19-sunset-overdrives-respawns-should-more-games-rethink-the-little-things|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} The game features an eight-player [[Cooperative gameplay|co-operative multiplayer]] mode called the Chaos Squad, which tasks players to complete a series of missions, as decided by the players themselves. Players defend vats of Overcharge Delirium XT from waves of OD'd at night and stop their progression by setting up fortifications and barriers, in a manner similar to [[tower defense games]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/features/sunset-overdrive-coop-is-a-thrill-ride-and-a-half--tgs-multiplayer-handson|title=Sunset Overdrive Co-op Is a Thrill Ride and a Half: TGS Multiplayer Hands-On|first=Heath|last=Hindman|work=[[Game Revolution]]|date=September 20, 2015|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuI7GJ6s?url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/features/sunset-overdrive-coop-is-a-thrill-ride-and-a-half--tgs-multiplayer-handson|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} It is inter-connected with the single-player mode allowing players to transfer their story character, with all the weapons and gadgets they have already accumulated, to the mode.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/09/18/how-multiplayer-works-in-sunset-overdrive|title=How Multiplayer Works In Sunset Overdrive|first=Marty|last=Silva|work=[[IGN]]|date=September 18, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuI9pbjs?url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/09/18/how-multiplayer-works-in-sunset-overdrive|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} Although players work together, players also try to earn more Style points during play than their co-op partners.{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/06/10/e3-2014-hands-on-with-sunset-overdrives-crazy-co-op-mode |title=E3 2014: Hands on with Sunset Overdrive's Crazy Co-op Mode |last=Albert |first=Brian |work=[[IGN]] |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] |date=June 9, 2014 |accessdate=August 8, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808014633/http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/06/10/e3-2014-hands-on-with-sunset-overdrives-crazy-co-op-mode |archivedate=August 8, 2014 |deadurl=no}} == Plot == On July 13, 2027, FizzCo releases its new energy drink, OverCharge Delirium XT (also known as OCD), exclusively in Sunset City. In an attempt to sell OCD faster, FizzCo skipped health regulation protocols, leading to the drink being so toxic that anyone who drinks it transforms into a violent, [[boil]]-covered mutant known as an Overcharge Drinker (OD). In order to cover up the deception, FizzCo claims that a viral outbreak has happened and quarantines the whole city, preventing anyone from entering or exiting. The player, a FizzCo employee who works in the sanitation division, is saved from an attacking OD by Walter, a fellow survivor; the player is unaffected by the drink, as they were not allowed to attend the launch party for OCD, later referred to as "Horror Night". Upon learning that Walter is creating a plane to escape the quarantine, the player obtains the aid of Sam and the Oxfords, a group of rich but lazy geniuses. After multiple errands, the Oxfords build a propeller to complete the plane. The player joins Walter in his plane to escape the city and reveal the truth about the outbreak. At the last second, Walter notices an [[invisible wall]] preventing their escape and pushes the player out of the plane before dying in the subsequent crash. Still planning to escape, the player aids Troop Bushido, [[Scouting|scouts]] living in a [[samurai]] museum, and the Fargarths, a group of [[Live action role-playing game|larpers]]. In thanks, the two groups design and build a ship out of garbage which tricks the FizzCo sensors and allow them past. As the player is about to escape, they learn that FizzCo robots are attacking the Oxfords and Troop Bushido in order to kill all witnesses. The player returns to Sunset City and rescues the survivors. Sam informs the player that there is a deadly superweapon in FizzCo headquarters, which the player is able to break into after obtaining the help of Las Catrinas, a trio of [[La Calavera Catrina|skeleton]]-themed [[Mexican Americans|Mexican American]] cheerleaders caring for the children's ward of a hospital, by recruiting a band fronted by [[King Buzzo]] (voiced and [[mocap]]ped by the real [[Melvins]] singer){{cite web |url=http://paulsemel.com/exclusive-interview-sunset-overdrive-guest-star-melvins-singerguitarist-buzz-osborne/ |title=Exclusive Interview: Sunset Overdrive Guest Star (And Melvins Singer/Guitarist) Buzz Osborne |last1=Semel |first1=Paul |date=November 10, 2014 |website=paulsemel.com |publisher= |access-date=May 17, 2016}} to perform for the children. The player rallies the four factions to attack FizzCo headquarters, and attempts to destroy FizzCo HQ by riding a giant bottle of OCD into it (reminiscent of [[Dr. Strangelove]]). The player is killed in the blast, and the factions mourn them. However, the player stops the credits rolling after this scene to complain how depressing the ending is, and decides to change it. The player survives in this ending, and it is revealed that the FizzCo building is a robot that is meant to destroy the city to cover up the OCD outbreak. The player destroys the robot and has milk and crackers with the other survivors. After the credits, however, computers in the FizzCo headquarters automatically activate a protocol sending FizzCo helicopters full of OCD around the world. ==Development== ===Origin=== ''Sunset Overdrive'' was developed by Insomniac Games, which had mainly developed games for [[PlayStation|PlayStation consoles]]. Drew Murray and Marcus Smith, the game's creative directors, began brainstorming ''Sunset Overdrive'' after the completion of ''Resistance 3'' in 2011. They presented their ideas to Insomniac's owners and CEO [[Ted Price]], outlining a project that would borrow influences from the documentary ''Hyena Men of Kenya'', ''[[Tank Girl]]'' comics, the novel ''[[I Am Legend (novel)|I Am Legend]]'', the British television series ''[[The Young Ones (TV series)|The Young Ones]]'', Halloween masks from the 1960s, and [[Lego]]. The initial presentation failed to generate interest, but Murray and Smith were asked to come back a week later to explain how the game would actually be played. In their second presentation, they explained their vision of a game featuring fast-paced action that would be "the rock and roll end times". According to Smith this confused some team members who thought that they were making ''[[Brütal Legend]]''. The team received approval after their second presentation. After ''Sunset Overdrive'' was green-lit internally, Insomniac had to pitch it to a number of publishers. Insomniac wanted to retain brand ownership, causing some firms to opt out of publishing it. Murray and Smith traveled to Microsoft Studios a number of times to pitch the game to them. The main pitch began with the playing of "[[Kick Out the Jams (song)|Kick Out the Jams]]" by [[MC5]], and ended with Murray: "...on top of a chair, mimicking how the game was going to play, and the last minute heroics." Microsoft was eager to work with Insomniac and agreed to fund and publish the game.{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/05/09/how-sunset-overdrive-became-an-xbox-one-exclusive |title=How Sunset Overdrive Became an Xbox One Exclusive |date=May 9, 2014 |last=Moriarty |first=Colin |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] |work=[[IGN]] |accessdate=May 11, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuIHXRkC?url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/05/09/how-sunset-overdrive-became-an-xbox-one-exclusive |archivedate=November 9, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} The team originally did not want to make it a console exclusive, but they were impressed by Microsoft's philosophy toward the development of Xbox One, and the capabilities of [[Xbox Live]] features, which allow the initiation of a "two-way dialogue" with players.{{cite web|url=http://www.videogamer.com/xboxone/sunset_overdrive/news/insomniac_explains_reasons_behind_sunset_overdrives_xbox_one-exclusivity.html|title=Insomniac explains reasons behind Sunset Overdrive's Xbox One-exclusivity|first=James|last=Orry|work=VideoGamer.com|date=June 17, 2013|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130915214024/http://www.videogamer.com/xboxone/sunset_overdrive/news/insomniac_explains_reasons_behind_sunset_overdrives_xbox_one-exclusivity.html|archivedate=September 15, 2013|deadurl=no|df=}} ===Design=== Choosing a name for the game was the first thing the team did before starting development. They decided on the name ''Sunset Overdrive'' because they felt it was unique, and captured the feeling of the "grindhouse" from the 1970s.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-05-08-sunset-overdrive-was-originally-the-insomniac-version-of-dayz|title=Sunset Overdrive was originally "the Insomniac version of DayZ"|first=Stace|last=Harman|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=May 8, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuITuush?url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-05-08-sunset-overdrive-was-originally-the-insomniac-version-of-dayz|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} The project was originally conceived as an open world [[survival game]] similar to ''[[DayZ (mod)|DayZ]]''. The initial version of the game did not feature the traversal system, nor the unusual weapons included in the final version, and was described as "grounded" by Murray. In this version, players were tasked with scavenging resources during daytime, and defending their base at night. This later evolved to become the game's cooperative multiplayer mode. It employed the animation model from Insomniac's previous game, ''Fuse''. The direction of the game changed after the team watched a video based on [[Gorillaz]], and Murray gave up the idea of a realistic survival game.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/videos/how-a-gorillaz-video-and-jet-set-radio-inspired-su/2300-6418874/|title=How a Gorillaz Video and Jet Set Radio Inspired Sunset Overdrive|first=Aaron|last=Sampson|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=May 20, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuIOVqWR?url=http://www.gamespot.com/videos/how-a-gorillaz-video-and-jet-set-radio-inspired-su/2300-6418874/|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} He then asked the team to start prototyping ideas for a game that they thought would work. Some team members came up with the idea of having skateboarding elements in the game, which led the development team to start working and experimenting with a new traversal system. In hindsight, Murray described the shift in focus as an "organic, evolutionary process".{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/09/16/sunset-overdrive-was-originally-the-insomniac-version-of-dayz|title=Sunset Overdrive Was Originally The Insomniac Version Of DayZ|first=Mitch|last=Dyer|work=[[IGN]]|date=September 16, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuIUY8Tq?url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/09/16/sunset-overdrive-was-originally-the-insomniac-version-of-dayz|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} As the game's development progressed, the team began to draw on elements from other video game franchises such as ''[[Prince of Persia]]'', ''[[Jet Set Radio]]'', and ''Tony Hawk's Pro Skater'',{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/5/8/5692070/sunset-overdrive-xbox-one-insomniac-games|title=Sunset Overdrive turns the post-apocalypse into an energy drink-fueled party|first=Michael|last=McWhertor|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=May 8, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuIY27v7?url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/5/8/5692070/sunset-overdrive-xbox-one-insomniac-games|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} and put the emphasis on momentum. In 2013, the team had released ''Fuse'', which was a critical and commercial failure. The team now reflected on the reasons for its poor reception, and felt that they should go back to Insomniac's roots — developing unusual titles with vibrant visuals — instead of another dark shooter like ''Fuse''.{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/5/8/5684982/sunset-overdrive-fuse-insomniac-games|title=How Insomniac learned from Fuse and got its groove back with Sunset Overdrive|first=Michael|last=McWhertor|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=May 8, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuIZ3jA9?url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/5/8/5684982/sunset-overdrive-fuse-insomniac-games|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} They also thought that ''Sunset Overdrive'''s stylization should reflect the personality of the company, and that building a world that has a sense of humor and irreverence was something the team was eager to do. [[Ted Price]], CEO of Insomniac Games, described it as a game Insomniac had wanted to develop for a long time. The game's producer, Bryan Intihar, called it: "...the game [they've] been meaning to make for 20 years." Microsoft supported it and shared the same vision and the idea of creating something new.{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2014/11/10/insomniacs-ted-price-on-sunset-overdrive-working-with-microsoft-and-more/|title=Insomniac's Ted Price on Sunset Overdrive, working with Microsoft, and more|first=Jeff|last=Grubb|work=[[VentureBeat]]|date=November 10, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuIbPVsw?url=http://venturebeat.com/2014/11/10/insomniacs-ted-price-on-sunset-overdrive-working-with-microsoft-and-more/|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} According to Price, Insomniac wanted to "break the rules of shooters". He felt that the [[History of video game consoles (seventh generation)|last generation]] of shooters had established a formula of staying behind cover for defense, and leaning out from it to attack. He wanted to change that pattern with ''Sunset Overdrive''{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/sunset_overdrive/b/xboxone/archive/2014/05/08/insomniac-s-ted-price-talks-open-world-lessons-learned-from-fuse.aspx|title=Insomniac’s Ted Price Talks Open World, Lessons Learned From Fuse|first=Tim|last=Turi|work=[[Game Informer]]|date=May 8, 2014|accessdate=October 2, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuIdVOZ8?url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/sunset_overdrive/b/xboxone/archive/2014/05/08/insomniac-s-ted-price-talks-open-world-lessons-learned-from-fuse.aspx|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} by encouraging players to attack in an aggressive manner and to focus on momentum. To accomplish this, the team developed a city that supported parkour and fast movements. They also hoped that with the introduction of a [[History of video game consoles (eighth generation)|new generation]] of video game consoles, they could establish a new standard for the genre which would "retrain" shooter fans playing the game. Smith compared ''Sunset Overdrive''{{'}}s gameplay to [[pinball games]], where a player's every movement has consequences, and the on-screen chaos created by players is based on their actions.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/how-sunset-overdrive-is-like-pinball/1100-6422689/|title=How Sunset Overdrive Is Like Pinball|first=Daniel|last=Hindes|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=October 2, 2012|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuIf91B7?url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/how-sunset-overdrive-is-like-pinball/1100-6422689/|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} The game's combat and traversal elements were originally separate from each other, but were later connected as the team began to think that: "shooting while grinding was fun". The combination of these aspects led the studio to adjust the game's world design. The team calculated how the city should be designed so that it could support both combat and traversal. As a result, they ensured that the world was built in modular 4x4 blocks, and that no surface featured an angle that was between 26 and 45 degrees. Furthermore, the team considered how long grinds should be, and decided that they should be at least 8 meters in length. The grinds were designed to be longer than usual in enemy-concentrated areas so as to allow additional time for players to consider both combat and traversal options. In order to encourage experimentation, the game features a vertical map-design, in which the difficulty the enemies' players face increases as they move towards higher ground.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-05-08-insomniacs-sunset-overdrive-is-a-shooter-that-plays-like-jet-set-radio|title=How Insomniac's Sunset Overdrive mixes gunplay with rail-grinds|first=Stace|last=Harman|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=May 8, 2015|accessdate=October 2, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuImlDD9?url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-05-08-insomniacs-sunset-overdrive-is-a-shooter-that-plays-like-jet-set-radio|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} Insomniac described the game as "a celebration of games", in which the team pushed existing concepts in a new direction.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/sunset-overdrive-dev-says-no-one-has-ever-made-a-g/1100-6422576/|title=Sunset Overdrive Dev Says No One Has Ever Made a Game Like This|first=Eddie|last=Makuch|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=September 26, 2015|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuInl0hN?url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/sunset-overdrive-dev-says-no-one-has-ever-made-a-g/1100-6422576/|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} Besides drawing influences from ''Prince of Persia'', ''Tony Hawk's Pro Skater'' and ''Jet Set Radio'' series of games for the game's traversal system, they drew influences from ''[[Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure]]'' for their "Next-Gen Respawn" system, ''[[Scott Pilgrim]]'' and ''[[The Omega Man]]'' for the game's setting, and ''[[Peggle]]'' when they were creating the game's weaponry. The game's humor was inspired by Insomniac's own game series ''[[Ratchet & Clank]]'' and ''[[Spyro the Dragon (series)|Spyro the Dragon]]''. There are also references to other pop culture icons such as ''[[Breaking Bad]]'' and ''[[Portal (video game series)|Portal]]''. Despite that, Smith said that the game would be completely different from ''[[The Last of Us]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/xbox-one-exclusive-sunset-overdrive-is-the-opposit/1100-6422690/|title=Xbox One Exclusive Sunset Overdrive is "The Opposite of The Last of Us" says Insomniac|first=Daniel|last=Hines|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=October 2, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuIqlHiR?url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/xbox-one-exclusive-sunset-overdrive-is-the-opposit/1100-6422690/|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} The game's character creator function allowed players to create different kinds of combinations in an [[Avatar (computing)|avatar]]. The team ensured that there were many customization options, including allowing players to "dress like a crazy person". The developers felt that this feature would suit the story, because the game's city enters a state of anarchy, where [[social norms]] no longer exist. The team wanted the character creator to feature diversity, so that players could build an avatar based on their own choices. They found the process of introducing diversity challenging. As a result, a system was developed that broke the character creator down into three different categories: mainstream, street (emo and goth), and costume. The team originally added [[role-playing games]]-styled stats to the game's costumes, but later decided to scrap that so that players "would just choose what they thought looked cool."{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/07/25/sdcc-14-the-cool-character-customization-of-sunset-overdrive|title=SDCC 14: The Cool Character Customization Of Sunset Overdrive|first=Evan|last=Campbell|work=[[IGN]]|date=July 25, 2015|accessdate=October 2, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuJBz5vi?url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/07/25/sdcc-14-the-cool-character-customization-of-sunset-overdrive|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} ===Art and setting=== {{quotebox|quote=When we got off of Resistance 3, which is a very dark, dystopian world, but right for that game, we said, 'Let's do something fun. [...] OK, let's create a character whose life is shitty in the modern world. And when the apocalypse comes, it's like a dream come true.|source= — John Paquette, the game's lead writer|width=33%}} The game is set in a near-future, post-apocalyptic world. The team wanted to try something different, unwilling to return to a setting that was similar to ''Resistance 3''.{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/sunset-overdrive-interview-insomniac-games-james-stevenson-colour-character-90s-influences-1466574|title=Sunset Overdrive Interview: Insomniac Games' James Stevenson On Colour, Character and 90s Influences|first=Ben|last=Skipper|work=[[International Business Times]]|date=September 22, 2014|accessdate=October 2, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuIuNooM?url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/sunset-overdrive-interview-insomniac-games-james-stevenson-colour-character-90s-influences-1466574|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} Instead of depicting a world with a dark atmosphere and gritty environments, the catastrophe that occurs in the game's story line is referred to as an "awesomepocalypse” that transforms the user's initial view of the game's world as a "playground" for players to explore and do whatever they want – "emphasizing the fun of free {{sic|re|ign}} during end times."{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/sunset_overdrive/b/xboxone/archive/2014/05/08/insomniac-s-colorful-open-world-theme-park-of-violence.aspx|title=Sunset Overdrive: Insomniac’s Colorful, Open-World Theme Park Of Violence|first=Tim|last=Turi|work=[[Game Informer]]|date=May 8, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuIvDQqQ?url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/sunset_overdrive/b/xboxone/archive/2014/05/08/insomniac-s-colorful-open-world-theme-park-of-violence.aspx|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} The goal was to make players feel that the post-apocalyptic world in ''Sunset Overdrive'' is fun and limitless, delighting and lively, instead of a place that is dreadful and worrying.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/features/sunset-overdrive-interview-insomniac-games-xbox-one-exclusivity-mature-themes|title=Sunset Overdrive Interview: Insomniac Games Talks Xbox One Exclusivity, Mature Themes, and More|first=Alex|last=Osborn|work=[[Game Revolution]]|date=August 8, 2015|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuIxS84w?url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/features/sunset-overdrive-interview-insomniac-games-xbox-one-exclusivity-mature-themes|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} To achieve this, vibrant and vivid colors were used to create the game's world and the team hoped that by tweaking the nature of the setting, the game would be "self-aware, humorous, and fun". The team also intentionally avoided creating a very serious tone because the final product needed to be entertaining and comparable to games like ''[[Crazy Taxi (video game)|Crazy Taxi]]'' and ''[[Jet Grind Radio]]'', instead of something too serious that looked like an [[interactive movie]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/09/05/creative-director-discusses-the-light-hearted-tone-of-sunset-overdrive|title=Creative Director Discusses The Light-Hearted Tone Of Sunset Overdrive|first=Cassidee|last=Moser|work=[[IGN]]|date=September 5, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuJ0Q0XX?url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/09/05/creative-director-discusses-the-light-hearted-tone-of-sunset-overdrive|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} The team emphasized "fun trumps realism" and reflected that through the "Next-gen Respawn" system, unrealistic weaponry, and the game's visual style.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/gaming/news/a579364/how-sunset-overdrive-is-trying-to-break-the-rules-of-shooter-games.html#~ppWXuwsYUzZntn|title=How Sunset Overdrive is trying to break the rules of shooter games|first=Matthew|last=Reynolds|work=[[Digital Spy]]|date=June 22, 2014|accessdate=October 2, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuJ13iI5?url=http://www.digitalspy.com/gaming/e3/news/a579364/how-sunset-overdrive-is-trying-to-break-the-rules-of-shooter-games/|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} While the game features colorful graphics that appeal to a broad audience,{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gucrIzMEmrE|title=Sunset Overdrive Preview – Why Teddy Bears Trump Hand Grenades|work=[[YouTube]]|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|date=May 13, 2014|accessdate=October 2, 2015}} it was intended for a mature audience which is reflected in the game's story, dialogue, and characters' portrayals. The story was designed to be casual, but compelling. The game's setting is inspired by both ''I Am Legend'' and imagining [[Iggy Pop]] as the last person surviving in a post-apocalyptic world.{{cite web|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/entertainment/sunset-overdrive-creative-director-marcus-smith-interview-2014101711#axzz3nOx1LF6f|title=Sunset Overdrive creative director Marcus Smith interview|first=Daniel|last=Rutledge|date=October 17, 2014|accessdate=October 2, 2015|work=[[3News]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuJ7rinT?url=http://www.3news.co.nz/entertainment/sunset-overdrive-creative-director-marcus-smith-interview-2014101711|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} The team also wanted to create a satirical story, and explore the theme of [[Anti-corporate activism|anti-corporatism]].{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2014-10/30/sunset-overdrive|title=How Sunset Overdrive mixes satire and the apocalypse|first=Matt|last=Kamen|work=[[Wired.co.uk]]|date=October 30, 2014|accessdate=October 2, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuJ8yqT8?url=http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2014-10/30/sunset-overdrive|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} The [[punk rock]] style was implemented in the game because the game's directors thought that it reflected a sense of "aggression", which suited the gameplay. When designing the [[cover art]], the team collaborated with the English studio Ilovedust.{{cite web|url=https://www.vg247.com/2014/05/09/sunset-overdrives-box-art-is-bright-artistic-just-the-right-amount-of-wacky/|title=Sunset Overdrive’s box art is bright, artistic, just the right amount of wacky|first=Stephany|last=Nunneley|work=[[VG247]]|date=May 9, 2014|accessdate=October 2, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuJDak8Q?url=https://www.vg247.com/2014/05/09/sunset-overdrives-box-art-is-bright-artistic-just-the-right-amount-of-wacky/|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} They wanted it to be easily recognized and stand out from the cover art of other video games in stores. They also wanted it to represent the game's characteristics: "intensity", "fun in the end times" in a "dynamic and vibrant world". There were three different iterations of the cover art, with major changes made to the game's protagonist throughout its development, as the studio struggled with the protagonist's portrayal. Insomniac was ultimately satisfied with Ilovedust's finished art design.{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/features/2015/8/27/9207581/video-game-box-art|title=How Some of the Best Industry's Best Teams Make Cover Art|first=Blake|last=Hester|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=August 27, 2015|accessdate=October 2, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuJInNOa?url=http://www.polygon.com/features/2015/8/27/9207581/video-game-box-art|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} ===Technology=== Price called ''Sunset Overdrive'' the biggest game the studio had worked on.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/09/25/sunset-overdrive-dev-its-the-biggest-game-weve-ever-made|title=Sunset Overdrive Dev: 'It's The Biggest Game We've Ever Made'|first=Luke|last=Karmali|work=[[IGN]]|date=September 25, 2014|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuJJFfHF?url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/09/25/sunset-overdrive-dev-its-the-biggest-game-weve-ever-made|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} As it was the first open world game developed by Insomniac they had to deploy new design and development skills to produce it. The time and resources needed to develop the game also expanded significantly.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-09-28-sunset-overdrive-the-ted-price-interview|title=Sunset Overdrive: the Ted Price interview|first=Wesley|last=Yin-Poole|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=September 28, 2015|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuJN08Pi?url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-09-28-sunset-overdrive-the-ted-price-interview|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} While developing the game's world, the team broke it down into 10 to 11 hexes and zones. They are classified into three different types: low resolution zones, shadow zones, and mission zones, and they overlap each other so that they can keep all zones loaded at the same time. Sunset City had three different iterations. In the early stages, it was called Greenlight City, based on [[Burbank, California]]. This version of the city featured interior structures that could be explored by players, and existed when the game's core concept revolved around "scavenge, craft, defend". This city was replaced with "Razor City" when skateboarding, which later became oil slicks and trampolines, was introduced to the game. Razor City was "Neo-Tokyo"-styled, but was later replaced by Sunset City which was more organized. While designing the game's [[artificial intelligence]], the team thought that the game's enemies must force players to use the traversal system while simultaneously engaging in combat with them. Because of the game's vertical design, the enemies were designed to adopt the game's vertical map-design. The team also developed a “nav position tracker”, which programmed these enemies to detect the location of players and find an ambush point.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/244865/How_Insomniac_squeezed_lastgen_tech_to_build_the_openworld_Sunset_Overdrive.php|title=How Insomniac squeezed last-gen tech to build the open-world Sunset Overdrive|first=Bryant|last=Francis|work=[[Gamasutra]]|date=June 3, 2015|accessdate=October 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuJOyay5?url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/244865/How_Insomniac_squeezed_lastgen_tech_to_build_the_openworld_Sunset_Overdrive.php|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} The game is powered by an internal engine developed previously by Insomniac Games for its game ''Fuse''. The engine of the game was reworked and optimized for the Xbox One.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/digitalfoundry-2014-vs-sunset-overdrive|title=Digital Foundry vs Sunset Overdrive|first=David|last=Bierton|date=October 28, 2014|accessdate=October 2, 2015|work=[[Eurogamer]]}} The game runs on 900p at 30 [[frame rate|frame rate per second]]. The game originally ran at a higher definition of 1080p, but it was decided to fix it at 900p so that more actions and enemies can appear on-screen.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/sunset-overdrive-dev-explains-why-it-chose-900p-ov/1100-6423080/|title=Sunset Overdrive Dev Explains Why It Chose 900p Over 1080p|author=Eddie Makuch|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=October 21, 2014|accessdate=October 21, 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuIEEWJs?url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/sunset-overdrive-dev-explains-why-it-chose-900p-ov/1100-6423080/|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} ===Audio=== Development of the game's music was led by Boris Salchow, who had composed scores for Insomniac's previous games ''[[Ratchet & Clank: A Crack In Time]]'', ''[[Resistance 2]]'' and ''Resistance 3''.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/pressreleases/228743/BORIS_SALCHOW_COMPOSES_ECLECTIC_CINEMATIC_SCORE_FOR_INSOMNIACGAMES_SUNSET_OVERDRIVE.php|title=Boris Salchow Composes Electric Cinematic Score For Insomniac Games "Sunset Overdrive"|work=[[Gamasutra]]|date=October 27, 2014|accessdate=October 2, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuJihuyK?url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/pressreleases/228743/BORIS_SALCHOW_COMPOSES_ECLECTIC_CINEMATIC_SCORE_FOR_INSOMNIACGAMES_SUNSET_OVERDRIVE.php|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} He collaborated with composers from Microsoft Studios, and Pyramind music studio. The design team wanted the composers to implement eight different styles of music for eight different sections featured in the game. However, this idea was dropped as being confusing and overly-chaotic. The team wanted to achieve a "high energy vibe" for this title and the resulting soundtrack features a lot of [[punk rock]] and [[electronic dance music]]. Fourteen different bands and artists were hired to perform the music often avoiding using [[musical instruments]] and writing lyrics for the game instead.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/new-sunset-overdrive-soundtrack-arrives-tomorrow-h/1100-6424366/|title=New Sunset Overdrive Soundtrack Arrives Tomorrow, Hear Some Tracks Now|first=Eddie|last=Makuch|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=December 22, 2014|accessdate=October 2, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuJlCZeF?url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/new-sunset-overdrive-soundtrack-arrives-tomorrow-h/1100-6424366/|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} The game's soundtrack was also inspired by works from [[FIDLAR]], [[DZ Deathrays]] and [[Ty Segall]].{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/gaming/decoding-the-secret-sauce-in-sunset-overdrives-soundtrack/|title=Kick Out The Jams, MOFOS: Secrets of Sunset Overdrive's Punktastic Soundtrack|first=Mike|last=Mettler|work=iDigitalTimes|date=November 7, 2014|accessdate=October 2, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuJmwPGy?url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/gaming/decoding-the-secret-sauce-in-sunset-overdrives-soundtrack/|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} Composers tried to match [[beats-per-minute]] to the gameplay and traversal system. The game features a dynamic music system, in which in-game actions are reflected by the music. When there is more on-screen action, or when players perform kills, the music becomes more frantic and exciting to help players further immerse themselves in the game.{{cite web|url=http://www.hardcoregamer.com/2014/10/23/the-dynamic-music-of-sunset-overdrive/113571/|title=The Dynamic Music of Sunset Overdrive|first=Adam|last=Beck|work=[[Hardcore Gamer]]|date=October 23, 2014|accessdate=October 2, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuJoAKE5?url=http://www.hardcoregamer.com/2014/10/23/the-dynamic-music-of-sunset-overdrive/113571/|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} ===Release=== ''Sunset Overdrive'' was among one of the first Xbox One exclusives revealed at Microsoft's press conference at E3 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/sunset-overdrive-news-release-date/|title=Sunset Overdrive trailer revealed at Microsoft E3 presser|first=Lorenzo|last=Veloria|work=[[GamesRadar]]|date=June 10, 2015|accessdate=October 2, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuJsvrXu?url=http://www.gamesradar.com/sunset-overdrive-news-release-date/|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} The first gameplay details were revealed by gaming magazine ''[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]'' in May 2014.{{cite web|url=https://www.vg247.com/2014/05/08/sunset-overdrive-details-emerge-from-latest-issue-of-edge/|title=Sunset Overdrive details emerge from latest issue of Edge|first=Stephany|last=Nunneley|work=[[VG247]]|date=May 8, 2014|accessdate=October 2, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuJtT03D?url=https://www.vg247.com/2014/05/08/sunset-overdrive-details-emerge-from-latest-issue-of-edge/|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} A gameplay demo and a release date announcement happened at [[E3 2014]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/06/09/e3-2014-sunset-overdrive-release-date-announced|title=E3 2014: Sunset Overdrive. Release Date Announced|first=Luke|last=Karmali|date=June 9, 2015|accessdate=June 9, 2015|work=[[IGN]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cuJvyGEY?url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/06/09/e3-2014-sunset-overdrive-release-date-announced|archivedate=November 9, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} Insomniac had worked solely for the [[PlayStation]] family for about twenty years, and the announcement of ''Sunset Overdrive'' being an Xbox exclusive led to speculation that the relationship between [[Sony]] and Insomniac had ended. Overdrive'' received positive reviews. It received aggregated scores of 83% from [[GameRankings]] based on 63 reviews and 81/100 from [[Metacritic]] based on 89 reviews. The game's tone was praised by reviewers. Daniel Bischoff from [[Game Revolution]] praised the game's comedic elements describing them as "contemporary". He added that the game is one of the rare few that made him laugh while playing. Sam Prell from [[Joystiq]] appreciated the humor, and thought that its quality was boosted by the performance of the voice-actors. His opinion was echoed by Peter Brown from [[GameSpot]], who found the voice acting in the game entertaining and believable. However, Prell considered some humorous moments "hit-or-miss". Andrew Reiner from ''[[Game Informer]]'' described the game as a "full circle", in which Insomniac has incorporated all the elements from their previous game into this one. As a result, he thought that while the story emphasized comedy, it successfully reflected some pressing issues existing in society. Mollie L Patterson from ''[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]'' appreciated the game's humor, but noted that it would not be able to satisfy every type of player. Arthur Gies from ''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]'' described the story as "gleefully stupid", and commended the self-aware narrative. Chris Carter from [[Destructoid]] praised the jokes featured in the game. However, he disliked the story, which he thought failed to offer motivation for players to complete the game. ''Sunset Overdrive''{{'}}s gameplay was also commended by many reviewers. Prell compared the game favorably to ''[[Jet Grind Radio]]'', ''[[Saints Row The Third]]'', ''[[Infamous (video game)|Infamous]]'', and ''[[Ratchet & Clank]]''. He singled out the traversal system, which he thought was fluid and well-executed. He added that the fast travel system was not useful in this game, since players can find a lot of fun by simply traveling between different locations in the game's world. He thought that all of the game's systems intertwined with each other, and ultimately made the game a complete and worthwhile experience. Reiner echoed similar thoughts, and considered getting around ''Sunset City'' fun for players. He added that the traversal system increased the game's replay value. However, he was disappointed by the game's occasionally repetitive mission design. Sliva and Brown shared similar thoughts, with the latter saying that the game featured too many fetch quests. Patterson disliked the game's traversal; he found that the system was frustrating at times. However, he thought that this problem lessened as players unlocked new moves and skills. Gies felt overwhelmed by the traversal options. He added that Insomniac had successfully created a system that was accessible for ordinary players, while creating challenges for those who want to master the system. However, he noted the camera system may not able to track the movement of the character accurately. He further commended the game's world design, and described it as one of the most "navigationally sophisticated" worlds he had ever experienced in a game. Bischoff considered the shooting mechanic "loose", but thought that the problem was overshadowed by the game's forgiving aiming and steady difficulty curve. Lucas Sullivan also criticized the mechanic, calling it "inconsistent". The customization options received acclaim. Bischoff praised the arsenal of weapons featured in the game, which he thought was deep, interesting, and creative, benefited by the Amps system, which added additional complexity to them. Prell described it as the "king" of the game. He praised the game's ability to allow players to customize their characters, and considered the weapons featured "varied", and thought they enhanced the game with personality. Reiner thought that all of the weapons featured in the game were fun to use, and that the amps system made experimenting with different weapons rewarding. Patterson also commended the game's weapons though he was initially skeptical about them. Gies thought that the customization options allowed players to play the game as they preferred, and described the character creator as "flexible". Marty Sliva from [[IGN]] praised the Amp upgrade system, which he felt encouraged players to try out unusual ways to experiment with it. The game's art style was applauded. Bischoff praised the colorful graphics and the different graphical effects featured in the game. He further praised the game's presentation, which he thought would lead "the Xbox One console’s personality this generation." Reiner compared the colorful graphics of the game to ''[[Sesame Street]]'', and thought the bright colors "[electrified] the screen". Reiner also praised the "Next-Gen Respawn" system, and the protagonist's animation. Sliva praised the design of the city, as he thought it featured a unique artistic style, and aided the traversal system. He added that the game's visuals "pop", and compared them to the "Easter Bunny on an acid trip". Carter praised the variety existing within the game's world, which he considered has prevented the game's world from being repetitive, and made landmarks easily recognizable. Brown thought that the game did not look realistic, but felt this did not stop the game from being one of the best-looking games available for the console. Sullivan also praised the use of colors, which he found was organic and vibrant. The game's multiplayer received mixed reviews. Prell thought that the mission-design was varied, and the voting system kept the mode from being repetitive. He also praised the interconnected structure between the single-player and multiplayer, noting that the items that could be carried over from multiplayer to campaign made the mode feel rewarding for players. Reiner thought that the action featured in this mode is satisfying, but thought that the system lacked enough depth and complexity to engage players. Patterson echoed similar thoughts, and felt that the ability of players to switch between the campaign and the Chaos Squad mode made the multiplayer mode a rewarding experience. Brown criticized the mode, saying that its difficulty was not properly scaled. The game was the second best-selling game in the UK on its release, and was outsold by ''[[FIFA 15]]''. In its second week of release, it was the eighth best-selling game.{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2014/11/10/uk-charts-cod-advanced-warfare-finally-fishes-out-fifa/|title=UK Charts: CoD Advanced Warfare dethrones FIFA|first=Sinan|last=Kubba|work=[[Engadget]]|date=November 10, 2014|accessdate=April 11, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-11-03-sunset-overdrive-debuts-second-in-uk-chart|title=Sunset Overdrive debuts second in UK chart|first=Tom|last=Phillips|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=November 3, 2016|accessdate=April 11, 2016}} === Accolades === {|class="wikitable sortable mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" style="border:none; margin:0; width:100%;" |+ '''List of awards and nominations for ''Sunset Overdrive''''' |- ! {{ Medical anthropology}} {{Anthropology}} '''Transpersonal anthropology''' is a subdiscipline of [[cultural anthropology]] and [[transpersonal studies]]. It studies the relationship between [[altered states of consciousness]] and [[culture]].
==Definition and context== According to Walsh and Vaughan,<ref name="Walsh & Vaughan 1993">Walsh, R. and F. Vaughan. On transpersonal definitions. ''Journal of Transpersonal Psvchology'', 25:199-207, 1993</ref> who proposed several definitions of the transpersonal field in the early 1990’s, «Transpersonal anthropology is the cross-cultural study of transpersonal phenomena and the relationship between consciousness and culture.» Charles Laughlin,<ref name="Laughlin 2013"> Laughlin, C. D. (2013). The ethno-epistemology of transpersonal experience: The view from transpersonal anthropology. ''International Journal of Transpersonal Studies'', 32(1), 43–50.</ref> a founder of the field of Transpersonal anthropology, has defined the discipline as «the cross-cultural study of transpersonal experiences, including the sociocultural evocation, interpretation, and utility of transpersonal experiences, and their involvement in defining social roles».
As with [[transpersonal psychology]], the field is much concerned with altered states of consciousness (ASC) and [[transpersonal experience]]. However, the field differs from mainstream transpersonal psychology in taking more cognizance of cross-cultural issues—for instance, the roles of [[Mythology|myth]], [[ritual]], [[diet (nutrition)|diet]], and [[Literature|texts]] in evoking and interpreting extraordinary experiences.<ref name="Young & Goulet 1994">Young, David E. and J.-G. Goulet (1994) ''Being Changed by Cross-cultural Encounters: The Anthropology of Extraordinary Experiences''. Peterborough: Broadview Press.</ref>
==History== Sheppard <ref name="Sheppard 2006"> Sheppard, E. (2006) "Our worlds beyond." ''Transpersonal Psychology Review'' 10 ,(1):63-70. </ref> has noted how transpersonal anthropology can be said to have begun in the USA in the 1970s. By the mid-eighties the discipline was described as a «young and growing field» by commentators.<ref name="Valle & Harari 1985"> Valle, Ronald S. & Harari, Carmi. Current developments in...Transpersonal Psychology. ''The Humanistic Psychologist'' 11, Vol. 13, NO. 1, Winter 1985</ref> There was, by this time, also a development at the organizational level, in the form of the ''Association of Transpersonal Anthropology'', with its supporting publication, the ''Phoenix''.<ref name="Valle & Harari 1985"/> According to Hunter,<ref name="Hunter 2015"> Hunter, Jack. "Between Realness and Unrealness": Anthropology, Parapsychology and the Ontology of Non-Ordinary Realities. ''DISKUS'' 17.2 (2015), 4-20 (The Journal of the British Association for the Study of Religions)</ref> the parallel field of [[Anthropology of Consciousness]] grew out of the transpersonal perspective, including Transpersonal anthropology.
Central to the development of the field has been the work of anthropologist [[Charles D. Laughlin]], who is considered to be one of the primary founders of the discipline.<ref name="Hartelius 2014 "> Hartelius, Glenn. The Imperative for Diversity in a Transpersonal Psychology of the Whole Person. ''International Journal of Transpersonal Studies'', 33(2), 2014, pp. iii-iv</ref> However, Shepard <ref name="Sheppard 2006"/> also notes the contributions of Ihsan Al-Issa, <ref name="Al-Issa 1995">Al-Issa, Ihsan . (1995). "The Illusion of Reality and Reality of Illusion." ''[[British Journal of Psychiatry]]'' 166 (3)368-373.</ref> and [[Edith Turner (anthropology)|Edith Turner]],<ref name="Turner 1996">Turner, Edith (1996) ''The Hands Feel It: Healing and Spirit Presence Among a Northern Alaskan People''. DeKalb, IL: Northern Illinois University Press.</ref> wife of the anthropologist [[Victor Turner]].
==Contributions to academic theory== One of the contributions of Laughlin to anthropological theory is a differentiation between so-called monophasic and polyphasic cultures. According to this theory polyphasic cultures are open to altered states of consciousness, and tries to integrate these experiences into their worldview, while monophasic cultures, typical of technocratical societies, are largely closed to these alternative states of mind.<ref name="Laughlin 2013"/><ref name="Hartelius 2014 "/> Laughlin has published extensively on the topic of Transpersonal anthropology, and has addresses several issues within the field, including methodology.<ref name="Laughlin MacManus Shearer 1983">Laughlin, Charles D., McManus, John and Shearer, Jon (1983) "Dreams, Trance and Visions: What a Transpersonal Anthropology Might Look Like". ''Phoenix: Journal of Transpersonal Anthropology'' 7 (1/2):141-159.</ref><ref name="Laughlin 1988">Laughlin, Charles D. (1988) "Transpersonal Anthropology: Some Methodological Issues." ''Western Canadian Anthropology'' 5:29-60.</ref><ref name="Laughlin 1994a">Laughlin, Charles D. (1994) "Psychic Energy and Transpersonal Experience: A Biogenetic Structural Account of the Tibetan Dumo Practice," in ''Being Changed by Cross-cultural Encounters: The Anthropology of Extraordinary Experiences'' (ed. by D.E. Young and J.-G. Goulet). Peterborough: Broadview Press, pp. 99–134.</ref><ref name="Laughlin 1994b">Laughlin, Charles D. (1994) "Transpersonal Anthropology, Then and Now." ''Transpersonal Review'' 1(1): 7-10.</ref><ref name="Laughlin 1994c">Laughlin, Charles D. (1994) "Apodicticity: The Problem of Absolute Certainty in Transpersonal Anthropology." ''Anthropology & Humanism'' 19(2): 1-15.</ref>
The work of Al-Issa <ref name="Al-Issa 1995"/> has dealt with the topic of hallucinations, and the cultural aspects of them. Here, Al-Issa notes how not all cultures have negative views on hallucinations. Cross-cultural differences are noted by Al-Issa in sensory modalities most commonly encountered in hallucinations.
The field also includes the theories of anthropologist Dennis Gaffin whose contribution is a re-conceptualization of fairyology and the [[fairy]]-faith within the context of anthropology.<ref name="Leykam 2013"> Leykam, A. E. Book Review: Running with the fairies: towards a transpersonal anthropology of religion. ''Choice'' ; Middletown Vol. 50, Iss. 6, (Feb 2013): 1099. </ref><ref name="Butler 2015"> Butler, Jenny. Book Review: Gaffin, Dennis. 2013. Running with the Fairies: Towards a Transpersonal Anthropology of Religion. ''Fieldwork in Religion'', 10.2 (2015), 252–254</ref>
Sheppard<ref name="Sheppard 2006"/> explains how Edith Turner's interpretations of her husband's field studies among the [[Ndembu]] in [[Zambia]] also can be interpreted as belonging to transpersonal anthropology, insofar as her interpretations of their [[healing ritual]]s were transpersonal.
==Criticism==
Sheppard <ref name="Sheppard 2007">Sheppard, E. (2007). Anthropology and the development of the transpersonal movement: Finding the transpersonal in transpersonal anthropology. ''Transpersonal Psychology Review'' 11(1) 59-69 {{ISSN|1366-6991}}.</ref> has published an article criticising transpersonal anthropology, at least as it has typically been practiced in contemporary scholarship. Her criticisms include its lack of a systematic conceptual base; its over-emphasis on shamanism; the difficulty in studying non-Western cultures that have been truly immune to Western influences and the question of the extent to which transpersonal anthropology has really addressed [[altered states of consciousness]].

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/81.36.17.212|81.36.17.212]] ([[User talk:81.36.17.212|talk]]): unexplained content removal ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.4)

[[File:The Tribunal de las Aguas of Valencia.jpg|thumb|The ''Tribunal de les Aigües'' of Valencia in 2006]] The '''Water Tribunal of the plain of Valencia''', also known as the '''Tribunal of Waters''' ({{lang-ca-valencia|Tribunal de les Aigües de València}}) is an institution of Justice to settle disputes arising from the use of irrigation water by farmers in several Irrigation Communities ({{lang-ca-valencia|Comunitats de Regants}}) and [[canal]]s (''Quart'', ''Benàger i Faitanar'', ''Tormos'', ''Mislata'', ''Mestalla'', ''Favara'', ''Rascanya'', ''Rovella'' and ''Xirivella'')<ref name=Website>{{cite web|title=Acequias of Valencia|url=http://www.tribunaldelasaguas.org/en/|website=Tribunal de las Aguas de la Vega de Valencia|accessdate=2 December 2015}}</ref> in the [[Horta de València]].
In 2009 it was chosen along with the [[Council of Wise Men of the plain of Murcia]] as [[intangible cultural heritage]] by [[UNESCO]].<ref>{{cite web| title=Irrigators’ tribunals of the Spanish Mediterranean coast: the Council of Wise Men of the plain of Murcia and the Water Tribunal of the plain of Valencia|url=http://www.unesco.org/culture/ich/RL/00171|publisher=UNESCO Culture Sector |accessdate=27 August 2014}}</ref>
==Proceedings of the Tribunal== The Tribunal is a [[customary court]]. It consists of one representative, called a trustee, from each of the Irrigation Communities—nine in total—and one among them is elected president for a period of two years. Every Thursday the Tribunal meets in public and an administrative session at the Casa Vestidor at the [[Plaça de la Mare de Déu]] of [[Valencia]] to discuss various issues, mainly the distribution of water. On public holidays that fall on a Thursday, the Water Court meets on the preceding Wednesday <ref>http://www.visitvalencia.com/en/what-to-visit-valencia/monuments/list-of-monuments/monument/7834</ref>. That is when the bailiff, with the permission of the president, calls for cases from each of the canals in turn, with the traditional phrase "''denunciants de la sèquia de...!''" ("claimants from the irrigation canal of...!"). The trial takes place quickly and is completely in [[Valencian]].<ref name="Proceedings">{{cite web|title=The proceedings|url=http://www.tribunaldelasaguas.org/en/el-tribunal-ing/funcionamiento-ing|website=Tribunal de las Aguas de la Vega de Valencia|accessdate=24 July 2017}}</ref>
Each complainant puts his case before the Tribunal, and then the accused defends himself and answers questions. It is then when the Tribunal, with the exception of the trustee of the canal in question (to ensure fairness) decides the guilt of the defendant, and if so found, it is the trustee of the canal who imposes the penalty for the offender, according to the ''Bylaws of the Irrigation Communities'' ({{lang-ca-valencia|Ordenances de la pròpia Comunitat de Regants}}). The court is purely oral—there is nothing done in writing and no records are kept.<ref>http://www.valenciavalencia.com/sights-guide/sights-listings/tribunal-aguas-water-court.htm</ref>
==History== [[File:Tribunal de les Aigües Valencia.JPG|thumb|''Tribunal de las Aguas'' by [[Bernardo Ferrándiz]], 1865]] The Tribunal's origin is not fully known, although it is likely to have evolved from previous [[Al-Andalus|Andalusian]] traditions. Some historians such as [[José Vicente Gómez Bayarri]] placed its origins in Roman times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lasprovincias.es/valencia/prensa/20091115/opinion/agricultura-tribunal-aguas-valencia-20091115.html|title=La agricultura y el Tribunal de las Aguas en la Valencia musulmana|publisher=Las Provincias|trans-title=Agriculture and Water Court in Muslim Valencia|language=Spanish}}</ref>
The most widespread theory, but without any historical basis, is owed to [[Francisco Javier Borrull]]. His hypothesis is that there was already a precedent in Roman times, but its foundation as it operates today occurred during the reigns of the Caliphs [[Abd-ar-Rahman III]] and [[Al-Hakam II]], specifically in 960. Borrull's reason was that during the reign of these two Caliphs was an era of complete peace on the Iberian peninsula, and therefore it must have been founded then. In fact, the millennial anniversary of the founding of the Water Tribunal took place in 1960, led by [[Vicente Giner Boira]], legal adviser to the Tribunal at the time, and leading proponent of this theory in the twentieth century.
==See also== *[[Council of Wise Men of the plain of Murcia]].

[[Image:zinkevicius.jpg|thumb|Professor Zigmas Zinkevičius]] '''Zigmas Zinkevičius''' (January 4, 1925 in Juodausiai, [[Ukmergė district]] – February 20, 2018 in [[Vilnius]]) was a leading<ref>{{Cite book| title=Foreword to the Past: a Cultural History of the Baltic People |first=Endre |last=Bojtár |url=https://books.google.com/?id=5aoId7nA4bsC&pg=PA54&q= |page=54 | publisher=Central European University Press |year=1999 |isbn=963-9116-42-4}}</ref> [[Lithuania]]n linguist-historian, [[professor]] at [[Vilnius University]], and a full member of the [[Lithuanian Academy of Sciences]].<ref name=pirm/> He has contributed to studies in the history of languages, [[onomastics]]<ref name=IPC>Švietimo informacijų technologijų centras. [https://web.archive.org/web/20031120230807/http://www.ipc.lt/wg/php/wg.php?zs=24&zn=58 Zigmas Zinkevičius]. Retrieved on 2008-08-18</ref> and other areas.<ref name=pirm/> Zinkevičius was a recipient of the [[Herder Prize]], which was presented to him in 1994. Zinkevičius is the author of 30 academic books and several hundred scientific publications in various languages.<ref name=pirm/>
==Biography== After graduating from the gymnasium at [[Ukmergė]] in 1945, he enrolled in [[Vilnius University]].<ref name=pirm>{{Cite web|url=http://pirmojiknyga.mch.mii.lt/Asmenys/zinkevicius.en.htm |title=Zigmas Zinkevičius |accessdate=2008-08-07 |work=A Virtual Exhibition of a Millennium of Lithuanian Cultural Heritage |publisher=Institute of Mathematics and Informatics}}</ref> He studied linguistics until 1950. In 1955 Zinkevičius defended his thesis ''Lietuvių kalbos įvardžiuotinių būdvardžių istorijos bruožai'' (''Historical traits of adjective pronouns in Lithuanian language'') and received a Doctoral degree. From 1956 to 1962, Zinkevičius was Dean of the Faculty of History and Philology of Vilnius University. Together with his colleagues, he established a new classification of [[Lithuanian language]] dialects. For his work ''Lietuvių dialektologija'' (''Lithuanian dialectology'') (1966) Zigmas Zinkevičius received a Habilitated Doctor degree, and became a professor two years later. In 1973 Zinkevičius took a new position at Vilnius University as chairman of the Lithuanian language department, and beginning in 1988 served as chairman of the Baltic [[Philology]] department.
In 1982 Zinkevičius became a member of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Letters, History and Antiquities]]; in 1991, of the [[Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters]], and in 1995, of the [[Latvian Academy of Sciences]] and the [[Lithuanian Catholic Academy of Sciences]]. He was fluent in a number of languages, including [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]], [[Russian language|Russian]], [[Polish language|Polish]], [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]], [[Belarusian language|Belarusian]], and [[French language|French]].<ref name=seimas>[http://www3.lrs.lt/n/rinkimai/20001008/kandvl.htm-152734.htm Zigmas Zinkevičius]. Central Election Committee. Retrieved on 2008-08-18</ref> Zinkevičius is considered as the most cited Lithuanian linguist.<ref>{{Cite journal|title= Akademikui Zigmui Zinkevičiui – 80|journal=Universitas Vilensis| date=2005| first=Bonifacas |last=Stundžia |issue=45| url=http://www.vilnensis.vu.lt/archyvas/nr-45/akademikas.html|accessdate=2007-09-06 |language=lt}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
==Political activities== Zinkevičius worked as Minister of Education and Science under Prime Minister [[Gediminas Vagnorius]].<ref name=seimas/> He was a member of the [[Lithuanian Christian Democratic Party]] and was elected its chairman in 1999.<ref name=seimas/> Zinkevičius was a member of the [[Seimas]] (Lithuanian Parliament) in 2000–2004. He was also a member of the National Language Committee. He published a book discussing his experience as a Minister of Education ''Kaip Aš Buvau Ministru'' (''How I was a Minister'').
==Awards and prizes== Zinkevičius received these awards and prizes:
* [[National Advancement Prize]] ({{lang-lt|Nacionalinė pažangos premija}}), 2007 * The Commander's Cross of the [[Order of the Lithuanian Grand Duke Gediminas]], 1995 * [[Kazimieras Būga]] prize awarded by the [[Lithuanian Academy of Sciences]], 1995 * [[Herder Prize]], 1994
